Award.AwardTitle: Conference for African American Researchers in the Mathematical Sciences (CAARMS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Conference for African-American Researchers in the Mathematical Sciences (CAARMS) is an annual conference that allows minority researchers and students in the mathematical sciences from across the country to interact with each other as research mathematicians. Lectures are given by 12 invited speakers who are primarily African-American but not exclusively. The format of the conference allows all of them to give single hour, non-parallel lectures over at three day period. This is to ensure that all the participants of the conference are exposed both to the breath of African-American researchers in the mathematical sciences as well as the breath of the mathematical sciences themselves. Students are encouraged to attend and contribute to the intellectual activity of the conference by making poster presentations on the first day.

Young researchers attending the conference serve as judges for the posters. Awards are given to the students on the second day. On the third day, the winning students give short lectures about their work. Finally, there are refereed proceedings for some of the conferences. Five have been published to date. Future plans are to have a pre-conference workshop for undergraduate students who are beginning to learn about doing research in the mathematical sciences and one for young faculty on research collaborations and proposal writing. A permanent CAARMS website (www.caarms.net) is being developed that will encourage research collaborative activity throughout the year. The schedule for the next three CAARMS conferences is as follows:

CAARMS17 (2011)--Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM), June 1-4, 2011.
Chairs: Prof. William A. Massey (Princeton University) and Prof. Russel Caflisch (IPAM,
UCLA)

CAARMS18 (2012)--Stanford University, June 2012.
Chairs: Prof. William A. Massey (Princeton University) and Prof. Peter Glynn (Stanford
University)

CAARMS20 (2013)--Princeton University, June 2013.
Chair: Prof. William A. Massey (Princeton University)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mission: The Conference for African American Researchers in the Mathematical Sciences (CAARMS) came into existence in 1995 to encourage, nurture, and promote African American researchers in the mathematical sciences, current and potential. The mathematical sciences are defined in the broadest sense to include (in alphabetical order) computer science, machine learning, mathematical applications, mathematical theory, operations research, statistics, and other related technical fields where mathematics plays a major role. The conference also exists to complement and cooperate with other established groups that promote African-Americans in the mathematical sciences.

Program: The conference begins with a student workshop, named the J. Ernest Wilkins Workshop for Future Researchers, to give an introduction to the world of mathematics research. It is named in memory of the outstanding Black researcher J. Ernest Wilkins (1923 – 2011), still the youngest (at the age of 19) PhD mathematics graduate from the University of Chicago. CAARMS conferences have no parallel sessions and provide a platform to showcase the work of up to 10 African-American researchers per conference. They are all given 52 minutes (a micro-century) to talk about their research followed by questions. Additional lectures may also be given such as expository talks, working lunch discussions, or multiple lecture tutorials. All these talks are integrated with approximately 20 to 25 brief (2 minute) oral research presentations given by Black students from schools around the country. Their talks are an overview of poster presentations that they give at the end of the day. After researchers attending the conference judge their work, the award winners give longer (20 minute) oral presentations of their research by the end of the conference. This final event is named the David Blackwell Workshop for Future Research, in memory of the late Dr. David Blackwell (1919-2010). Dr. Blackwell, an outstanding research contributor to 20th century mathematical statistics. Both Professors Blackwell and Wilkins are shining examples of African-American researchers in the mathematical sciences who both attended the Institute for Advanced Study (IAS) as young researchers during the 1940’s.

Venues: CAARMS1, the first conference, was held in 1995 at the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute (MSRI) in Berkeley CA. We were fortunate to have both Drs. Blackwell and Wilkins in attendance. Our host was the late Dr. William Thurston, Fields Medalist and in 1995 the Director of MSRI. CAARMS23, the most recent and 23rd conference, was held in 2017 at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor MI. Below is a list of all the venues for CAARMS conferences in chronological order. The six conferences highlighted in blue and italicized were funded with the assistance of this National Science Foundation grant. After this list are group photos of those six CAARMS events.

CAARMS1 (1995)  – Mathematical Sciences Research Institute (MSRI)

CAARMS2 (1996)  – Bell Laboratories, Center for Discrete Mathematics and Computer Science (DIMACS), and the Institute for Advanced Study (IAS)

CAARMS3 (1997)  – Morgan State University and National Security Agency (NSA)

CAARMS4 (1998)  – Rice University

CAARMS5 (1999)  – University of Michigan

CAARMS6 (2000)  – Morgan State University

CAARMS7 (2001)  – Duke University

CAARMS8 (2002)  – Princeton University

CAARMS9 (2003)  – Purdue University

CAARMS10 (2004)  – Mathematical Sciences Research Institute (MSRI) and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory

CAARMS11 (2005)  – Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM)

CAARMS12 (2006)  – University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI)

CAARMS13 (2007)  – Northeastern University and University of Massachusetts at Boston

CAARMS14 (2008)  – Georgia Institute of Technology and Spelman College

CAARMS15 (2009)  – Rice University

CAARMS16 (2010)  – Johns Hopkins University (Mount Washington Conference Center)

CAARMS17 (2011)  – Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) at UCLA

CAARMS18 (2012)  – Princeton University

CAARMS19 (2013)  – University of California, San Diego

CAARMS20 (2014)  – Princeton University

CAARMS21 (2015)  – Institute for Computational and Experimental Mathematics (ICERM) at Brown University

CAARMS22 (2016)  – Princeton University / Institute for Advanced Study (IAS)

CAARMS23 (2017)  – University of Michigan

Impact: More than 100 recent Black mathematical science PhDs have attended CAARMS conferences as graduate students. Moreover, over 40 recent tenured Black professors in the mathematical sciences have all attended previous CAARMS conferences as graduate students, assistant professors, or non-academic researchers.
